content.description:
This nice warm up route has mostly friendly holds although it is a bit cerebral.  It is the fifth route from the left and is the last bolted route at the end of the crag.  It is an easy matter to top out on this route and set up a TR anchor on the route

K2

, but there is sharp rock between the two anchors, so do not run the rope between them.

The fourth route from the left has an interesting, tenuous start and remains sustained for most of the route.  From the top, you can see over the UAC fin and behold the beauty of Deer Creek Canyon.  This was named for JCOS Ranger extraordinaire, Mike Morin.

The second route from the left, MITFL has a tough start and angles up to the left on easier ground ending close to the anchor of

Gneiss Lee Done

.  Look for the hidden humper hold 2/3rds the way up.  A top rope from this anchor can be used to TR the nefarious 5.11a start/route between

GLD

and MITFL.  Big shout-out to Mr. Lane, the man behind the Bosch.  We couldn't have done it without you!

This is the last route on the right side of the crag.  It is a great cruiser warm-up that will give you an introduction to what the climbing is like at the UAC.  Starts with a left-facing flake and cruxes early.  Continue through the surprisingly (although not entirely) solid, kitty litter band to the anchor.  The anchor is accessible from the top.   Take care on the bushwhack up as it gets deceptively close to the edge.
content.protection:
Top rope anchor - a block slung with a cable.

Apparently, someone (not the original developers) has bolted this route for leading. Well ... great I guess.  I might have been nice if you asked....

content.description: This is the third route from the left, and it is smack dab in the middle of the crag.  An easier start gets reachy fast and a sustained crux starts about ½ way up.  It has a crimpy finish.  This was named after Castlewood Canyon legend (so he says), Tom Hanson, whom isnt a hasbeen at all.

So far the farthest left (and lowest) route, GLD starts near a boulder.  Inspect this boulder to find a surprise.  The route starts on good feet but gets tenuous quickly.  Trend up to the right and think your way through some blankish sections.  There are many places where you feel you just might fall off this one.  The anchors are within reach of the

Mike in the Fast Lane

anchor.
